I would comment that the current trend in perspective on the reasons for the observable gender and race gaps in STEM (and other fields) still seems rather narrow to me. Don't get me wrong - I agree fully that work needs to be done in bridging gaps and improving diversity, for the benefit of all!

That being said. From this vid the key concerns I'm picking up are a) the statistical uneven representation of groups and b) unconscious and institutionalised biases. Now, certainly these two are significant. I'm not sure that on their own, these 2 factors dig deep enough into the problem to root out and address it's cause.

Let me give an example. I am honestly not confident that diversity quotas in workforces really address the issue. The reality of quotas is that, as was touched upon briefly in the video, there IS a risk of less qualified individuals entering into roles with advantage over others. But perhaps more than that, it's almost 'forced' diversification. Over time you could say that forcing the institution to address and change its lack of diversity will have a feedback effect which changes institutional biases from the inside. Maybe that's true! I can see the logic there. However the perspective has a significant issue in my mind, and that's the assumption that institutional biases are the only/main significant cause.

Anecdotally, I've seen and heard some disturbing statements in my work wherein colleagues have been hired into roles on a diversity basis. I've watched it happen, I know it's real, and I do have a problem with other - demonstrably more capable - individuals being denied valuable opportunities on the basis of promoting. The risk here is real but arguably invisible harm, especially in fields like medicine and healthcare. I've seen the impact. As I say this is an anecdote. But it is also a real concern that I don't feel should be dismissed.

I agree fully with promoting and enhancing diversity, it's so important and marginalised individuals have so much to offer and that is also being denied. My point is, we need to take these statistics, look at these biases, and root out the deeper causes no matter what those figures are. As the guys state in this video: a 'good' scientist will take any result and allow it to mold their perspective. A similar approach is vital to truly addressing these inequalities.

I make no claims as to what these root causes may be. But systemic racism and statistical imbalances aren't, in my mind, the beating heart of these inequalities. In some ways I can see them as symptoms. And if we want to cure this chronic issue, we need to weed out the cause.

Just some food for thought! I'm super interested to hear some other perspectives. Thanks for taking the time to read. (:

You can't fight racism with more racism. Hiring minorities, because they are minorities, is racist. I'm a minority in STEM, and yeah, there's a lot of white people. Why? If anything you have to blame public schools. Which I don't even want to get into right now. You know how to change this without being racist? Instead of forcing inclusion, through racist hiring procedures; encourage more minorities to pursue these fields. If more minorities pursued these fields, then the numbers would eventually normalize. Yes, anecdotes are not evidence, and I am sure you could find examples of all white professors, and all white graduating classes; that doesn't change the fact that the issue can't be fixed by adding more racism. Instead of fueling the fire, encourage more minorities to take an interest in science at a younger age, and then help to nurture that. Too often do I hear the cry's of "I hate math" or "I hate science". This is what we need to focus on. I'm from a country where education was free until recently. These people simply didn't care or didn't want to. It has a lot to do with their own culture. If their parents give them different values from birth, they will go another way. There's also a VERY clear difference between the 1st and 2nd generations. It seems the longer they stay within our "white culture", the more they'll also go towards the same goals in life. However, most non-whites here simply care more about different things. They tend to start their own businesses and a lot of'm are perfectly succesful with this... They themselves carry a responsibility here. They refuse to work with us and they try to do everything differently.

I'm not saying this goes for everybody everywhere, but I am saying that even though my country is a great many leagues ahead of the US, the representation difference is still very clear. Some points for people to consider:


1) Saying "Google isn't as bad as X" is not the same as saying "Google dosen't have any structural problems with it's hiring or promotional process".


2) Racism is acting on racial prejudice for another group (not refering to structural racism here). It is possible to be racist to Black and Hispanic people, and not to Asian people.


3) Examining hiring and promotional practices is not about lowering the bar - it's a about casting a wider net. I'm sure there are many potential superstar Google employees at institutions like Howard, and it would be very helpful to know which institutions these organisations tend to hire from; they could be missing out on some great talent.


4) Saying "Systemic Racism in the education system is the main cause of these inequities" is great, but using that as an excuse to not try to improve company hiring practices, is not.


5) Representation is important. It's very easy to take this for granted as a white person, but for young people especially, seeing someone who looks like them in a professional role that interests them gives them, without it being said, implicit permission to do the same.

I'm lucky to go to a good school who are fighting for change, but I know that many of New Zealands universities are not doing this.

My question is, is there any research to indicate whether or not this apparent bias is not institutional racism or discrimination, but rather the result of some other statically significant factor? For example, is it possible that we don't see as many women, (or different cultural/racial groups, etc), in these types of roles because statistically these "science community minorities" are less inclined to be engaged in the science community, but equally more engaged in other similarly meaningful areas that resonate with them differently than science appears to resonate with white men? Maybe I'm completely wrong, but I think that this is a question that doesn't appear to get asked, (in my experience anyway), in discussions about apparent racial/gender inequalities.

I'm completely open to being proven wrong, and definitely agree that this appears to be a problem, but I feel that it's only scientifically fair to consider all possible explanations for an observation before making a final judgment.

So I want to start off by saying that I appreciate the motivation behind this video, you mean well and I appreciate that. There were things I agreed with, but may I suggest a slightly different take on this. I am a 17 year old girl, and I've almost finished my first two years of college as a chemistry major, so this type of thing comes up around me a lot because people feel the need to emphasize the fact that I am a women in a STEM field. Because of the idea of equal outcome instead of equal opportunity, when I apply to a college or try for a scholarship I am more likely to get into the college or receive the scholarship, which I think is ridiculous. I think the best way to work towards solving the issue instead of just making another issue would be to keep things anonymous. Let the people reviewing your application for whatever you're applying for see your records, like grades and achievements, but don't mention race or gender. I think it is INCREDIBLY important that everyone have equal opportunity, but you can never truly have equal outcome. I come from a family who's women prospered in education; my mother has a PhD in mathematics, my Aunt has a PhD in psychology, and there's more examples. And yes, they faced bias, my mother was flat out told that it might be hard to find an assistantship because she's a women. But I think we're now turning it around into discriminating against white males especially, and that's NOT a good way to go. Just because someone is a man doesn't mean they should have an advantage against me as a women, and vise versa. I have a passion for science, and one of my pet peeves is when politics start messing with things. I will forever fight for true equal opportunity, however equal outcome is not something that can be guaranteed.

As a woman going into electrical engineering the article "Why Do So Many Women Who Study Engineering Leave the Field?" by Susan Silbey always pops into my head: "[W]omen tend to leave [engineering] at a higher rate than men. Women make up 20% of engineering graduates, but it’s been estimated that nearly 40% of women who earn engineering degrees either quit or never enter the profession. Clearly, some elementary and high school reforms are working, but those at the college level are not." (https://hbr.org/2016/08/why-do-so-many-women-who-study-engineering-leave-the-field)

Do we need? No we don't. We don't need to impose diversity in everything. You don't need to see a certain dominance in a certain field in society as a necessary problem. The sad truth is that these days everything where there's a dominance of mostly white male non-minority people, certain groups tend to see that as a problem. It reeks of misplaced political correctness, especially because there's no easily identifiable mechanism that would explain that certain demography. I live in a country where every person has the same opportunities of becoming a scientist regardless of background, as long as the person seizes the opportunity and there's still a significant difference. Do you then need to address such a difference? No, we don't. Especially, because those who want to address such differences often resort to the horrid concept of "positive discrimination" as if discrimination ever could be positive. Try explaining for instance to someone that he can't become such or so because there are not enough she that want to become. I shudder to see this positive discrimination in action. As an example: in my country electoral lists must be equally composed of men and women, which has the very unfortunate consequence that lists get filled with incompetent women figureheads simply because parties don't find enough competent women who want to be on an electoral list. The era that you couldn't attend university because you were not of the right demography is now at least a few decades ago. Unless you can show me a clear discriminatory mechanism like that creating a certain demography in science now, please accept it and move on. Again, it's not because in a field a certain demography has a dominance that there's a problem: In the first half of the 20th century physics was dominated by people of Jewish descent. There was no problem with that until certain ideologies made it a problem. Certain fields in athletics are dominated by certain demographies: i can't find any problem in that, it's just the way it is.

I realize that sort of information could be difficult to find, if it even exists somewhere. It would also be interesting to see percentages (by ethnicity) for how many people are actually IN STEM fields, and maybe also what the percentages are for the general population. If the percentages of minorities in STEM fields is lower (and I would guess that may be the case), it would stand to reason there are fewer with YT channels, working at FB, etc. I am not implying that minorities are any less capable, but they may have more problems getting into some colleges, or finding good positions after college, etc. There is also the possibility that some groups may not WANT to (statically speaking) to study certain fields. I know that probably sounds racist, but I think different cultures value certain things more than others, and this influence what fields different ethnicities gravitate towards. Are there more Hispanics in construction because there is a cultural value placed on working with their hands, or because it is a good career they can get into (due to sociological reasons)? I honestly have no idea, but I wouldn't be surprised if it was some of both).
I believe systematic racism does exist, but I don't think it's the only problem. The problem will probably take generations to completely eliminate. Until college student populations roughly resemble the general population, it will be impossible for any group (be that YouTube channels or Facebook employees, or the unemployment line) to be an accurate representation of the general population. And the unemployment line will be the final test; when those in the unemployment line reflect the local population, racism will finally no longer be an issue.

To address the other elephant in the room, a recurring theme among a lot of these science channels is a tendency to do work exclusively with very elite universities, such as Harvard, MIT, UC Berkely, NYU, Oxford etc. I understand that many sci YouTubers were educated at these universities, but it has come to the point where "normal" colleges are rarely, if ever, featured. As a STEM student of a "normal" public university, I feel my school isn't interesting or worthy enough ever to be featured, despite the amazing things we do.
It is important to mention that most immigrants and POC come from socioeconomic backgrounds that largely make attending those universities unattainable. Even speaking from my perspective as a middle-class white at a regular university, I struggle to relate to much of this content, even if it is the exact same field as mine. I can only imagine how daunting the impossible distance would seem for a younger viewer from a different background.

Hey guys! Great video, you've guys brought me some reflections and delivered a pretty good discussion about how diversity can lead to more innovative ideas.

Just a quick suggestion, I'm a person from a Latin American country (Brasil, so not really in the Hispanic category, we are lusophonic, but I mean, I've learned and can understand some Spanish) and I have some regards about the "Latinx" word use.
Typically, when we lusophonics try to adapt our language to embrace non-binary identities, we tend to add the letter -e at the end (Examples: Lindo, Linda, Linde), this is still a new concept, specially for latin derived languages that use grammatical genders. But that's what a language is, a alive being, always mutating itself to meet the needs to express something.
From what I was told, the -x at the end make it hard to people with some kind of disability with their vision understand what is written, since they use the accessibility option of screen reader, and the -x at the end is impronounceable both in Portuguese and Spanish, and it also sounds like a term that anglophonic people coined, not really a thing that was created genuinely and organically by us.


So yeah, to be more inclusive, you could say Latine or just Latin American Person/people. I know I can't speak for all of my lusophonic fellas out there, let alone all the Hispanohablantes. And I understand that was not the main topic of the video, nor your report, since it was someone else's data analysis.

Regardless, this was an awesome video with an important topic that really needed to be spotlighted! Wish you guys the best!

Let me preface this by saying that, yes we have come a long way from the way things were in the past, and that many people respect others and do not disciminate, but the comments section and like to dislike ratio really dissapoints and discourages me. As a young woman about to start college as a math and physics major, to know that there is this much hate for diversity in STEAM is hurtful to say the least. I have been discoraged countless times, to enter physics with the only reason given being that I am puerto rican woman, so it would be "too difficult for me". This is dispite the fact that I almost always had the highest grades in math and science, and the fact that all my teachers said that I'm "naturaly talented in it".  Whenever I have conversations about astrophysics with my best friend (also a woman) on the train, we always get dirty looks from men. Most of the time (there are exceptions don't get me wrong), if I start talking about physics to a group that is predominately male, they will assume that I don't understand very basic and intuitive ideas dispite the fact that I have read countless books on the subject. If I start discussing a topic like dark matter or black holes, they will always try to silence me or one up me. (side note they never do any of the things I just mentioned to other males). On top of this, my calculus teacher (an absolutely brilliant woman) dreamed of becoming an engineer. The only reason why she is not an engineer today is because the employer literaly told her, "Your perfectly qualified, but a woman can't do the difficult work of engineering". I can go on about my experiences and the experiences I've heard from others, but I think you get my point. Wether you want to believe it or not, there is still an obserd amout of discrimination in STEAM, and it is this discrimination that prevents minorities (who are just as compitent) from entering their desired feilds. This is a discussion that needs to happen, and is something that needs to be understood by everyone in the community (men, women, ect). Until the day comes were nobody will be assumed to be less compitent, capable, or intelligent based soley on their gender identity, race, sexual orientation, or ethnic group, I will not stop fighting for diversity in STEAM. I'm greateful for this video, and to those that actually read this and respect my experiences (even if you disagree).

I am a science communicator and host of a science communication podcast. I am also a minority and I am surprised that very few people notice this or talk about this as it is a weight I feel whenever I watch science videos on YouTube. This is not to say, I think the Top 25 are all excellent science communicators but it is a little disheartening to see they are all white: we really need to think about the pathways that bring people to that position and how we can create new pathways that bring diversity in.

Journalism is one of the least diverse career fields in the US with about 70% of journalists being white. Science writing, which includes science journalism and PIOs, is almost 90% white according to a National Association of Science Writers survey in 2018. Though we don't have data on other forms of science communication, we can assume things are just as bad and we need to do something.

Representation matters and we should strive for it but there is more. The lack of representation not only means a lack of innovation and perspectives, it also means certain stories don't get told. This is a problem that NASW members acknowledged and are committed to telling more diverse stories. That may be all good and fine but there is the problem of perspective: they are going to tell these supposedly "diverse" stories through a white lens. In the end, it's just preserving racism within the institution of journalism and giving it a pretty more diverse face. It's colonialism all over again.

I think more has to be done. I want more to be done.

As you pointed out, the higher up you go, the whiter it gets. I know from experience, and minority friends, you can get excluded from the meetings you need to get your job done and eventually get promoted because someone neglected to send an invite or thought you "won't be interested." Even if a company says they want to be more diverse and hires accordingly, those newly hired diverse employees either don't survive very long or aren't promoted as quickly as their white counterparts.

And this discrimination exists everywhere: think Conde Nast and Bon Appetite.

I think Janet Stovall, who in the Ted Talk, "How to get serious about diversity and inclusion in the workplace" gets it right. To solve the problem we need to fire people. We set targets and goals of what diversity and inclusion looks like for a company and, if those goals are not met in a certain amount of time, you fire the people responsible and who failed to implement that change in the workplace.

We do this in all businesses. We do it with sports teams. We set goals and if the person in charge fails to meet those goals, they are fired. Diversity and inclusion goals should be no different.

I work for a biotech company in the San Francisco area in California. We’ve been talking about this subject for a long time and have implemented several different forums. The fact that there is so many dislikes on this really shows how people are not understanding what this problem is. This video is not attacking you for being white. It's not saying you are racist for being white. I'ts not saying you are a bad person for being white. I'ts not saying that great scientists such as Einstein are any less great for being white.

What this is saying is that science builds on itself. And simply because of the sheer amount of time we've been doing it, it has been built upon some outdated ideas. All this video wants is for us to try to be more aware of our unconscious biases so we can find the objective truth. This is why we have double blind studies, to remove our biases as much as possible.

All this video is urging you to do is to try and be a bit more self aware. When you decide to think something about someone don't be afraid to challenge your thoughts.

This doesn't mean you need to second guess yourself constantly. Even if you only find yourself doing this once a month that's still an improvement overall, and it can only help society progress. Every little bit helps, and we can't wait for yours. :)

As a software developer for over 20 years, I have never even thought about race or gender, only good code or bad code. But in the last few years, it seems forced diversity has become more important than the quality of the software. Just look at Twitter being busy doing a search-and-replace on their codebase to remove terms that a few find offensive -- terms that does not affect the platform, and that is never visible to the user. Ironically the handle of the guy behind this madness is "@negroprogrammer" which for some reason isn't offensive. Another awful example is the very political Contributor Covenant that says a contributed feature can be rejected if someone doesn't like the contributor or something they have said in the past, no matter if the feature is long requested, needed or even essential.

To be honest, I don't recognize tech any more and it is making me depressed. What used to be about skill is now all about quotas. I'm actually starting to pull back from it all now that even the variable names in my code risk offending someone, and there are no sensible rules for what is offensive or not. It just doesn't feel like it is worth it trying to do something good for people and risk getting attacked by the outrage mob in return for some arbitrary reason that only makes sense to a select few.


Don't get me wrong, I welcome more women into STEM and software development, but not to fill a quota. I just hope the world comes to its senses before the things we depend on in our daily lives have turned into swiss cheese.

This video is a work of fiction.
The sources are rubbish, and repeated to imply for factual backing than there is.

The source for the list of popular stem youtubers is not cited, and a small sample size (25) is deliberately chosen to ommit data points that disagree with the videos primary assertion.
For example,
electroboom (Iranian), up and atom (female, not white), physics girl (female), minute earth as well as other channels by the same group (several female hosts), JerryRigEverything (science adjacent, like TKOR - disabled female cohost), viHart (female), many high quality mathematics study/tutorial channels (hosted by women), and the disproportionate number of indian electrical engineering channels, just off the top of my head.

The video also fails to take into account or even acknowledge the statistically expected demographic.
According to statista, 'internet penetration rate' is only 60% worldwide, with most net enabled population coming from the US, China, and India. With China and India as the exceptions, the more white a population is, the more likely they are to have access to the internet. Europe has a penetration rate of over 90%, and youtube is completely blocked in china.
On top of that, native english speakers have an advantage because 20% of the worlds population speaks english, and a much higher proportion of youtubes demographic speaks english.
The WHO says that 15% of world population is disabled. Most disabilities are invisible, and visible disabilities are more common in war stricken countries (with landmines for example), which are in turn less likely to have internet access.
The trans population proportion is small enough that it would be very surprising to see trans people represented in a sample size of 25.

In other words, any population of youtubers is expected to be made up of predominantly white, seemingly able bodied individuals.

I'm a science communicator at a children's science museum in Northern Illinois and our community has a large proportion of black families. My museum recently worked with the local afterschool programs to provide a curriculum that included hands-on activities tied to real world biographies. We found that the students were drawn to the scientists and engineers and inventors who they could identify with. We always had stories that were diverse with different POC and different abilities. The students particularly enjoyed it when the stories talked about people who overcame difficulties or who struggled in school. They love to hear that you don't need to start from a place of privilege to accomplish the things you want to do.

I read about a case where a women with physical disabilities was taken in for appendix removal, but while she was under the knife, they ALSO removed her uterus. Totally without her knowledge, totally without her consent, to the point where, years later, she was struggling to have children, went to the doctor, and learned the truth that way. So, technically, she ws a minor, but having had QUITE a few surgeries myself in life, I know that there's no "official age" at which someone can or can't give medical consent. Like I said, some disabilities here, too, but, like that woman, nothing intellectual, and AGAIN, that shouldn't matter. That shit is eugenics. Look up the case and try not to vomit.

This isn't about science. BUT, wanted to share my experience.
When I moved to the city, My friend and I applied for a warehouse job. Simple stuff. Packing, lifting boxes, loading, ect.
My friend got an interview a week before me and had started the job.
I received a phone call to come in for an interview a week later. When I came in for the interview, I was hired on the spot and I was asked if I had time to take a tour. I obliged. Everything went smoothly and then they told me to come in the following week to start.
A week later, just before my shift, I received a text from my boss asking me to come in to see him. Without having any remarkable credentials or prior job experience, I was immediately asked if I wanted to work in a higher position. I was of course surprised and accepted. I must have done made a great impression, I thought.
Well.. it's worth mentioning that my boss was white, while all of the people working in the warehouse, were Black, Hispanic, ect. My friend who applied was Cuban. Even more notable, I had far less of an impressive resume than my friend.
I had just graduated highschool. I find it hard to believe that I had something more than the other 200 employees working in the warehouse.

I ended up leaving this job as I found a position closer to home.
This sort of experience really made me realize how silent bias/racism can be.

Hey there! I'm a non-binary Filipino American, and I'm going back to college for the first time in nearly 20 years to get two more degrees: Environmental Science and Geography. After burning out of my banking career and traveling all over the world (25 countries / 5 continents and counting!), I realized I needed to get out of life's crossroads and find a new path. Several of the career aptitude tests I've taken have said I'd thrived in Earth Sciences, and it kind of makes sense; I enjoy being out in nature, and I find its various processes - especially in terms of chemistry and geology - very interesting. I've been out of work since February due to the pandemic, and I want to take advantage of the extra unemployment benefits and remote learning tech available now. It turns out that I nearly completed both associates degrees (with transferable units!) unknowingly back when I was doing my general education requirements all those years ago. It'll only take me a semester to finish each of them, and then I'll transfer and keep going.

Environmental Science and Geography seem like logical choices for long-term planning; the world will continue to change regardless of happens, and those who understand it best will be better prepared for it. Energy sources and consumption, food production and distribution, rising sea levels and the impact on coastal communities (I live near San Francisco), pretty much everything involving the Arctic Ocean... I focused mainly on logistics and auditing in my previous career, and those analytical skills will prove useful here as well. Geology was my third option, but I found that it requires a lot of advanced Calculus, which I haven't even looked at since I was a teenager. I'd basically have to relearn it from scratch. And given how we don't know how much longer the pandemic, remote learning, and financial benefits will last, I want to get as much done as I can.

In the meantime, my channel isn't science-focused; it's just a collection of various videos I've recorded during my adventures abroad. Check out my playlist on Iguazu Falls, the largest waterfall system on Earth! Or my ride on the Shanghai Maglev Train, the fastest train on Earth! I've also taken tens of thousands of photos. Beaches, mountains, jungles, glaciers, deserts, volcanoes, ancient ruins, UNESCO sites, you name it, I'm up for it. The photos that I've posted so far can be found here: https://500px.com/p/Polymathically

Claims and some of my thoughts:
1. White doctors treat black people differently
- This is unacceptable! Should be discussed and handled!
2. Black people and syfilis experiment
- Absolutely unacceptable! We can and should not tolerate this! Not solely because they were black people - but because it's a blatant violation of human rights!
3. "Nature" on trying to understand humans, and including few black and asian people
- I have not read it, but on the face of it, it seems wrong, and it should at least be heavily debated to combat bias.
4. Research on research
- I would find more information on this interesting. It's a major problem, if racist tendencies are the issue.
5. Diversity paradox
- It's interesting, and just another argument for the value of diversity!
6. Google and Facebook's workforce seems to indicate racial bias.
- It may seem so. I would love to focus on the proposed solutions to this issue.

Proposed solutions:
1. If scientists are surrounded by all white scientists, then it's a good time to bring up diversity
- Well, hard to disagree with.
2. Highlight more scientists or science communicators of other ethnicities.
- I'd hate for that to be necessary. I would love if we could just highlight the good stuff and not think about ethnicity at all, but maybe that's an outright naive thought... so sure :) It does make me kinda sad that the world perhaps cannot function like that by itself though.
3. Proposed solution to point 6 above: Hire more diverse people and create a culture and environment where people of different cultures actually want to work for these companies (Google, Facebook etc.).
- I can agree with that - the conversation seems important at least. But I'm not sure I understand how this should be implemented? Quotas? Encouragement? Financial encouragement? I would love something a bit more specific, to better understand what is proposed. I would really like to understand so I can try to form an opinion on the suggestion.
4. (I see that there is somewhat of an answer to my question in 3.) Public access to the breakdown of race and gender representation in specific jobs in specific companies.
- I can understand that you're curious about who is building the algorithms (mentioned in the video) - I think that it could be interesting to review that data too, and maybe investigate the results of the algorithms and why they give the result that they do.

Question:
1. You cite a paper that says: The more diverse last names there are on scientific research, the more likely those papers are to be cited more often - which points to "diversity = better quality science".
- My question here is - how do I or how do you know, that you're not biased yourselves in that assessment? I mean, if diverse papers were cites less than none-diverse papers, wouldn't you then conclude that "citing" is biased in favor of white people and then, by extension, that frequent citings are not an indicator of high quality science but bias against people of color? I'm just curious to learn your thoughts here.

Lastly you say:

Representation matters - well, I do not have a hard time believing that. I sort of wish it didn't, but it's probably a human trait, and I really do appreciate your video - it was good food for thought :) Thanks guys.

I think some people in the comments might be missing the point of why AsapSCIENCE included the list of science youtubers in the beginning. It's not at all to say that there's anything wrong with those specific youtube channels being hosted by white males. It's simply to point out that the perspective you see from the top science youtubers is largely from white males - meaning that there could likely be some different perspectives that you don't get to see. Being a white male doesn't make you any more or less credible than being of any other identity - it just means you don't necessarily have the perspective of other identities, and that can lead to a large information gap if the field you represent is dominated by people who share the same background.

I live in the UK and I'm a black Neuroscience post-grad student. In my time at both Universities I've attended, I've not had a single black lecturer at all in either the Biomedical science department at Bristol or the neuroscince and psych department in at Gold UoL.

It's definitely a little disheartening and for sure it makes me wanna work harder. I think it's also important to address the distribution of minorities amongst subjects. It seems that in practical subjects like engineering and computer science I see more black teachers by a long shot.

I know from experience that, at least in London, kids from African communities (which are often deprived) are encouraged by their parents to go further down the route of accounting, law and medicine than research science and honest to god, many families don't even understand the concept of research science. When I told my parents I was studying neuroscience, they thought I was gonna become a neurologist and I had to disappoint them but till this day they introduce me to their friends as "the neurologist" 🙃. So for sure to some extent the lack of representation in certain fields can be partially explained by a community perspective on what is and isn't worth doing.

More needs to be done to include minorities in science but more needs to be done within these communities to encourage an interest in these fields.

I think it's important to separate two forms of "institutional racism" that are talked about in this video.

It seems like you could strip everyone of any identity besides a number which represents a score for things like the income of their parents, the wealth of their community, the funding of their school, etc. You would see all the disparity that you mention in the field of science, college admissions, movie stars, and any field where we lack diversity. It all comes down to wealth inequality and inequality of opportunity. Yes, that correlates strongly with race, gender, and sexuality because of the past. And that's what I consider to be a useful definition of institutional racism. In that sense, institutional racism is as inarguable as inequality itself, because that's all it is - a phenomenon you notice when studying inequality. The problem has racist origins, but the solutions can be rather indifferent to race (policies can be purely based on equalizing financial equality). I don't actually like to use the term in this way though, because when people hear the word "racism" I think they can't help but ascribe it to human behavior, rather than an attribute of a system (which is what this definition is).

If you're talking about a hiring manager unconsciously favoring a white person, that's a totally different discussion. That is racism which has its roots in the human mind, which is what most people think of when they hear the word. We need to separate the two ideas of unconscious bias in individuals and what that adds up to in the larger system, and disparities that have their root in inequal opportunity (possibly because of racist myths, policy, etc.) or else we'll never get anything done. Both things are a problem, but I think we're constantly talking past each other because they are so different, require different solutions, some are harder to show than the other, etc.

I think this video doesn't do a great job at separating the two, or at least making mention of how important financial inequality is with regard to these problems. If we don't start thinking about how money creates the biggest divides in western society, we will never solve the problem.

Firstly, you gave examples of a period of time where there wasn't just racism, there was slavery, and of course some things were made in the name of science to justify that present action. Yes, there were a lot of rights that were literaly denied to minorities throughout the years, but now we are seriously trying to create laws, measures, and much more to have a better future for everyone. However, we cannot expect immediate results, since those will take some time to appear.

Moreover, we must be aware of wealth and how it is a huge factor in science, specially countries wealths and its predominante race and ethnicity. I see a lot of problems with this video.
First, it doesnt seem to have a cohesive message. While it begins with diversity in science education it quickly sways of to talk about systemic racism in general and not focused on the subject at hand.
Second, the sources chosen are repeats of what you hear in EVERY SINGLE ONE of these kinds of videos. While they are famous examples, basing the whole argument of systemic racism on only a few papers is the same unscientific fallacy causes such as climate change deniers use. Science is not based on single studies, but on the consense of a lot of reproducable studies, so searching for a bit more diversity in papers would be appreciated. In addition, it is known that being told the same information time and again can lead to strengthening of disbelief and dismissal regarding this matter.
Third, you completely forgo the reasons behind the representation mismatch. In the case of famous science youtubers, people from purely english speaking countries have an enourmous advantage, just based on the language compability. That leaves mainly the USA, the UK and Australia as main competitors. with the UK and Australia being predominately white, all the diversity comes from inside the USA, which IIRC has a black population of 10~15%. If you include the education suppression on minorities, not seeing a diverse set of personalities in the top ratings is to be expected. As for women, the nature/technical science branches sadly are still predominately studied by men, naturally lowering their presentation in science education.
The facebook/google workforce/leadership argument is overstating the matter. A lot of the asian part of the workforce is OUTSOURCED, so naturally they get a significant cut when you adress leadership positions. The other demographics(except for white) barely changed in percentages when the workfoce and leadership amounts were compared.

Just to clarify things, i strongly believe that systemic racism exists, but that doesnt mean that everything we see is caused by it. And this video didn't really help to spread awareness, instead it showed shaky argumentation that probably hurt the good cause more than it should.

relationship between things means that one is the cause of the other. or the sharpshooter fallacy Cherry-picking data clusters to suit an
argument, or finding a pattern to fit a presumption. Just because there is a gap in preformance between whites and blacks does not mean the cause is racism. There is also a gap between Asians and Whites where asians are out preforming whites. Does that mean the institutions are bias towards asians and racists towards whites. Also i believe this video implies the Black or white fallacy. Where two alternative states are presented as the only possibilities, when in fact more possibilities exist. For example it implies that either the most popular videos are majority white which means racism or that there is diversity(but does not say how much diversity is enough) therefore the institution is not racist. So you are either diverse and not racist or not diverse and you are racist. Aslo the way that you define racism is important. To most racism is belief that other groups are superior or inferior due to some physical attributes. If this definition is used which is quite specific, than things that can't think or believe can't be racist. Sure a system can be designed and implemented by racist people but the system itslef is not racist. The problem with this definition is that it is much harder to know if someone is racist because knowledge of their beliefs and thoughts are required. But if you broaden the definition and make it to were any gap between races is racism then you asign racism no longer to people but to the systems, language, laws that people create. This means that any "thing" can be racist as long as there is some difference between races. This is to vauge in my opinion.

Okay so here comes a very long comment but it's just some arguments I thought about during the video.

English is not not my first language bla bla bla...

For the Tuskegee study :

This study took place from 1932 to 1972, why did it end you might think? Because people thought about it and came to the conclusion that this study shouldn't continue because of racism etc...
News articles came in and exposed the study, the year after lawsuits were filed against its participants.
It is indeed an example of discrimination in science but it can't be compared to today's situation. People went against it 50 years ago and cancelled it, people would do the same today.

For the genetic researches:

You say that the institution is "ignoring" people from minorities. From what I can say it' not, https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-01551-x
The nature article in the end paragraph put a lot of emphasis on the "willingness of people" and "the willingness of researchers to share".
They gathered data from Estonian and UK DNA Banks. Now here is my question for you: As clearly said in this paragraph, the one who gives DNA for the research are DNA Banks that are willing to contribute to the research, so why don't we see Asian, Black etc.. DNA Banks listed in it? It isn't said that the researchers aren't accepting minorities' DNA so why jump to those types of conclusion?

For the publishing problem :

I typed "#CommunicationSoWhite" on google and got a website with a spreadsheet telling us about the percentages of people of colour in Journalism
https://academic.oup.com/joc/article/68/2/254/4958972

For the wage gap in STEM :

https://www.emerald.com/insight/content/doi/10.1108/01443331011054226/full/html
Wow there's not a lot in here, Did I do my research wrong ? I can't only find similar researches by typing that on the Internet so...

In the "Design" section we see that I concerned 14 000 male chemists, I don't think that's a lot but it is out of 88 000 chemists in the US so about 15%.

In my tech (IT), there have been many POCs I've worked with. Fully competent. Fully professional. The ONLY reason there is fewer is simply the POCs do not choose to enter this field in greater numbers. IT is more well rounded when there are POCs that have these skills. Yet, often doing other things as a career places their career path away from the STEM fields. Nobody holds them away from STEM via the quantity of melanin they hold. They choose another way.

In fact, if I had to summarize the whole 'privilege' concept, it comes down to 'the results gained from successful execution of good choices....repeated... over and over'.

If a person never makes those good choices to be put on a good path, that's on the individual or the mentors not fully explaining they have opportunity.

Systemic bias occurs when the mentors intentionally do not show those under their control that there is a better way up and out. If they willfully propagate the idea that you are stuck in one place and can't get out, they are saying you are not as valuable as those that are favored. That is the true haughty supremacist attitude that poisons the mind of so many. They give an idea that...'you are a victim, your worth is less, let me give you these benefits to soothe your pain. Vote for me next time to keep benefits coming.'. Instead, the mentor should give idea that...'you are a high value person, with high worth, you will be a great contributor to others lives, the world is best when you are at your best, let's find out what you are good at and develop those talents that you can use so that will help others.'

Unfortunately, in IT (and the different STEM fields) there is a 'right stuff' that prohibits everyone from choosing as an available option. Not everyone can do programming, create database schemas, edit DNS zone files, setup subnet masking, etc. This doesn't make one better, but skilled to do the task. Same with engineering, physics, chemistry, biology, etc. All of these fields have their own gatekeeper of skills required to do those kinds of jobs. If you NEVER choose to develop those skills and talents, you will NEVER do these things.

'PRIVILEGE' is all about the increase of life you get by the repeated good choices you make and your ongoing development while repeating those choices. Regardless of your starting point, you can improve...somehow.

Life does not guarantee success. Life guarantees opportunity to improve. Edison might not have discovered the way to make the light bulb work without the first 999 failures. Success is a process. Opportunity is your guarantee. What you do with opportunity is up to you.

Sadly there are still misconceptions about how biases in career paths work, which leads to arguments like 'but maybe [insert group here] are just less inclined to do this job for one reason or the other', or 'there are a multitude of social issues that impact [group]'s choice of study'. There has been enough research that, even though the western world is multicultural and that creates different subgroups in the population, the actual reason for specific groups actively not participating in certain fields of study/work is because in early life they are often discouraged; nurses are white women, cleaning people are Latina, doctors are white men, and rubbish collectors are black men. These set-in-stone images are part of our upbringing.

The problem with this is the solution. The fairest, most individualistic solution is to remove all biases and let everyone figure it out for themselves. Sadly, that is not how the human mind or society works. Whatever job you think of in your mind creates an image of someone you've seen doing that job (or a voice or smell or feeling for blind people). This is just our brains' way of understanding concepts. This means that biases in certain fields perpetuate themselves by everyone (minorities and the majority alike) semi-automatically. The only real solution, which isn't 100% equal but the only way to get the desired equitable outcome, is to artificially control diversity to open up these industries. This way, a more diverse group of people are inclined to follow education in non-diverse fields in the short term and in the long term we change the culture so that children who grow up in "the new world" might not feel pressured in one direction or the other. Eventually the mandated diversity isn't necessary, because the fields are already diverse, but to get there we'll have to force society into it.

An example of how this has worked in the past is Women doing "men's jobs" in the US during the second world war. Women, who were supposed to be stay-at-home mums according to societal norms, were actively encouraged (or shamed through propaganda) to work in factories, shops, on farms, etc. Both the idea of women in the workforce became a point of feminist pride and, as a woman, working in a factory was a point of personal pride. When the men came back from the war and wanted to change everything back, the women rebelled, because society had changed to include them and now they didn't want to go back. They were too proud (positive meaning of proud).

As seen in the example and experiments galore, we must first change the society and then our values will follow.

Ironically, ASAPscience allowed their own personal biases to get in the way of this video.
.
There's the scientific principle: "Correlation does not equal causation". Just because there's a pattern of something does not automatically mean one thing causes the other. That said, just because a pattern of racial disparity of populars YT creators does not automatically equal it is because of racism. Could it be a factor? Yes, 100%. But rather than jumping to the automatic assumption that it is, let's consider all the potential contributing factors and confounding variables which could lead to this outcome.
.
This oversimplistic thinking is not only a big problem in current discussions on racism (especially within the antiracism ideology), take the discussion over the gender wage gap. Is there an outcome gap? Yes, but the variables as to why this is are far more complex than simply "sexism".
.
This is not meaning to dismiss discrimination of any sort. This is meaning to emphasize we should be focused on getting the diagnosis of the problem correct rather than confirming our personal biases for equality and diversity.
.
As one of my inspirations Carl Sagan said: "Science is a way of thinking much more than it is a body of knowledge." Let us keep asking questions and less jumping to mass conclusions about groups of people based on the color of their skin. 😊❤️

For people saying that there is no stoping the minorities and women to come up with youtube channels with good content - just think for a minute, why are you not seeing them ? There is definitely something stopping this from happening, either not many 'non-white-men' science people are there or there are people but not as much as famous/talented as 'white-men'. Both of these scenarios are bad, in scenario #1 something is stopping the 'non-white-men' people systemically from pursuing science and in scenario #2 if there are enough 'non-white-men' science people but not famous, then there is some kinda bias. I believe that with if both groups are provided the same treatment, then there would have been equal representation provided the sample is large enough.

And if something is stopping this natural ratio from happening, then forcing that in the name of diversity is required up to certain level to solve this is my opinion.

A good example is Indian caste system, a few upper class has been oppressing the other classes, practicing untouchability, denying them education and other basic rights for over 2000 years. And the result - despite the lower class being the majority population (~70 to 80%), had very limited representation in all the fields like politics, management, law, art, media, education, you name it. And what did India leaders do? they put in reservation laws that made it mandatory for educational institutions and most government jobs to allocate x% to lower caste. This was done around 70 years ago and things have gotten better, this has encouraged people from families who never had any education to get educated, it relieved the effects of years of oppression. It drastically changed the lives of oppressed people.

If a set of people have been dominating something for a long time, its gonna take a long time for its effect to go away even if the current setup is an unbiased one and things like forced diversity programs are gonna speed up this effect to go away quickly. It may not seem fair but in the grand scheme it is a much required one.

I am 1000% cool with being named in this video! Thank you for calling all of us out! I am conscious of this and I think about my role and my position in this all the time. I won't speak for all science creators, but I'd like to share the standards and practices I've tried to put in place and/or am working towards in case it can help other creators or audiences:
- Seek racial and gender diversity in the scientists and sources I use for research
- Show diverse racial identities in animations, photos, etc
- Include non-European scientific perspectives and stories where possible
- Use my platforms on social media to promote non-white science communicators
- When working with teams behind the camera, make those teams diverse to include different racial and gender perspectives in all stages of creating

This is not an exhaustive list, and I know I have room for improvement in all of these areas. Thank you for making this video and reminding us all to raise the standards!

Hey there! I just wanted to quickly pop in and add my thoughts on this topic to the conversation. First off, I'd like to thank Greg, Mitch and the ASAP science team for putting out this video. Even though our ideas don't necessarily run along the same road, we are all heading in the same direction, that direction being equality. To see such arguing in the comments can make one a little disheartened, and therefore I think that we need to really sit down as a community and have a civil conversation. You have provided the start to such a conversation; let me, along with the rest of the viewers, be the next ones to take up that mantle. We are eternally grateful that you have taken the step to introduce this important issue into the lines of conversation in your community of next-generation scientists.

If it is alright with you, allow me to start off with the points which I agree with! Systemic racism is a very real issue in today's society, and I think that we can all concur with that statement. And indeed, we as a society need to be making steps towards equality. However, it is how we choose to achieve our collective goal of equality. If you'll allow me to insert an example: an ideal world, employers would hire solely based off of an individual's skill level; this would be a world in which factors like race, ethnicity, religious beliefs and such held no weight in the evaluation of a person's hire-abilty. However, in the real world, within corporations and similar collectives, we can be- even if it is unconscious, biased in our decisions. It is a fault that people from all around the world hold. Now, we have put forward many measures to try and combat this racism, including laws and checks and balances systems. This is where my point of view on how to deal with the problem differs from some of the those which the video presents. Please, do correct me if I have misunderstood what you have really conveyed! At timestamp 8:51, the video talks about hiring more diverse people and creating promotion opportunities for them! I agree! We do need more diversity in the field, as the statistics in the front half of the video clearly show. However, here is where I'd like to offer my opinion. Does adversity make a better employee? This may be an extreme example, but it is a truth in our society nevertheless. If companies had to follow a plan of recruitment where they had to maintain a strict percentage of diversity, would that really solve the problem? If a coloured and a white individual, both of the same skill level, apply for the same position, should the company hire the coloured individual simply to maintain that percentage of diversity within the company employees? (although that does beg the question of which the employer should really be hiring, as both ways would seem to be biased. Please, anyone who's reading this thread, I'd love to hear your ideas on how to solve this issue!) In my opinion, I think instead of "forcing" equality in the workforce, we should really be tackling the most fundamental of issues. We are all born equal, but it is these social factors that start introducing disadvantages into the lives of some. I think that the way to work around this concept of forcing equality may be to start making alterations to the educational system. Putting children on a equal playing field at a young age will rid them of these biased ideas which they may have otherwise carried with them into their adulthood. Xisumavoid, a lovely youtuber, does an amazing job explaining this concept, and I really do recommend giving his video a quick whirl and watch if you've got the time! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GjMciDEjWgM


Once again, I feel the need to thank Mitch, Greg and the team for putting together this video. People are bound to disagree, and instead of battling it out, we should use this video and the subsequent comments section as an opportunity to foster a healthy debate. Only those rational enough to engage in such conversation with those who disagree, are the people who are capable of making a change. This topic is so important in today's society, and I am beyond glad to see it being discussed in the scientific community specifically as well. As a young, Chinese, bisexual girl entering high school, I've always dreamed of one day working in STEM, and in my years of academic study, I've developed a passion for biochemistry that I hope I will be able to pursue in my latter years. Seeing role models like Greg and Mitch fight for the next generation of young scientists is such a heartwarming feeling, and for that, I must go a step further and extend my personal thanks to you. May I even toe the line further, and crown you the Queens of Spreading Science and Love. Please, I'd love to see people in the comments, and maybe even Greg and Mitch join in this conversation! We are so far from reaching our goal, and every shared idea contributes to our collective goal. One day, I'm sure we'll achieve it.

The statistics at 7:40 (or for that matter, any other statistics in the rest of the video) doesn't seem to "prove" institutional racism per se, but rather shows which groups of people tend to occupy higher positions compared to other groups. Consider, an estimated 76.3% (!) of the population of the US is White, 13.4% is Black, 5.9% is Asian, and 1.3% is Native American. As long as one of the groups doesn't outnumber the white population, there will always be more white people in these positions, simply because there are more of them. Not saying that institutional(ised) racism (i.e. preference over one another) doesn't play some role in it (see, 43% of Facebooks workforce is Asian, even though Asians consist of 5.9% of the US pop.), but ignoring the aspects concerning the composition of the population is a bit misleading.
Source (US Census 2019): https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/fact/table/US/PST045219)

Is anyone actually shocked by the result of breaking down jobs based on race? It's pretty obvious that it's a reflection of socioeconomic background. You can argue if that's due to institutional racism or it in combination with personal choice, but the job breakdown is always going to be a reflection of socioeconomic background that will be skewed more in favour of personal choice. This is for a few reasons:

There's an incentive on the part of whatever the institute is to have the best and brightest people working for them regardless of race, a racist institution won't be able to compete with a non-racist institution simply because they'll have access to fewer candidates.

Poorer people have less access to education, this is the unfortunate reality, but a race with a higher representation in this poorer demographic will have lower representation in higher skilled jobs. STEM institutes can't fix this problem simply by hiring based on race because if they do they will not be hiring the best candidates and will not be as competitive as possible. Poorer people essentially just have more hurdles on the path to success, while this isn't good, this isn't going to be fixed directly by employment, grants or scholarships will help, but this is a societal issue, not a STEM issue. If you'll pardon the pun, the root of the problem needs to be addressed but you are focused on the stem. Also, I doubt that simply seeing someone that looks like you succeeding isn't as helpful as actually being given the oppurtunites you need to succeed.

Finally, you're not taking into account what an individual wants to pursue. The point at which one considers themselves to be successful is in part shaped in relation to the success of one's parents. This could in turn effect the aspirations of those in high skilled jobs that come from a disadvantaged background and essentially just make them happier with less relative to those at the highest heights of whatever institution they work for. A similar trend is misinterpreted as sexism in the gender earnings gap; women, for whatever reason, tend to be happier than men at the same level of income. This means that men are more likely to ask for a promotion and contributes, along with hours worked and other factors, to the disparities in pay between men and women. I'm not saying these things are the rule but you're dealing with huge numbers of people. Another example would be the success of many Asian people relative to other races in the United States.

TL;DR: it's not as simple as racism, there's a mireade of constantly shifting factors that result in this outcome. If you address socioeconomic disparities things will balance out over time. Addressing the outcome will not fix the root of the problem, affirmative action is just impatient and discriminatory against particular individuals for reasons out of their control.

I've worked in IT, specifically the data space, for a decade-and-a-half. In that time most of my coworkers were white men. The next largest demographic I'd say is South Indian people, and I will say that that population, from my observation, seems to be a little bit more evenly spread between South Asian men and women. I've worked with precious few Black people or Latinx people, though there have been some exceptions. Latin folks were more represented when I lived in central California. I'd say one of the most interesting trends is all of the Black co-workers I've had in Tech roles have been immigrants from various countries in Africa. I've worked with people from Kenya, Senegal, The Gambia, and Morocco, but not one Black American. And I've been on a number of hiring committees in that time. The applicants I see are also not particularly diverse. What this suggests to me is at least some significant part of the problem is a pipeline issue. Somewhere along the line it seems to me we are preventing or discouraging people of color and women from getting a stem education or sticking with a stem career once they graduate. I know this is all anecdotal, and I don't expect this to be any grand evidence of the problem, but that's what I've seen in my career so far.

The way that the diversity reports by google and facebook are presented here seems misleading to me. In my opinion these numbers should be "corrected" to what percentage the races actually make up in the population, so I did exactly that.

I calculated the ratio of the percentage of employees of a race to the percentage of the race in the total population. A value close to 1 means that the percentage of people in the company is equal to the percentage of people in the population. For example if white people make up 63% of the population and there are 63% white people in the company, then thats a racio of 1. A value higher than one means the race is "overrepresented", a value lower than one means it's "underrepresented"

the only question I really have is regarding the diversity of different positions in large US based companies. In each case you showed the leadership of these companies was around 60% white, however, ~63% of the US population identifies as white, so doesn't this stat make sense in the grand scheme of things? I know the demographics of the US compared to large companies isn't a perfect comparison by any means, especially when considering the large wealth disparity between white people and people of color in the US and the fact that the class of a person often determines their ability to get an education that will qualify them for such jobs, but I can't help but feel that expecting a perfectly even distribution of racial diversity in a company based in a country where one race makes up ~63% of the population and another makes up ~1.3% is at least somewhat unrealistic and misguided. I'm not trying to say there isn't a problem with bias and discrimination in the hiring practices of big tech because there DEFINITELY is, I just think the way it is illustrated here is lacking some context.

Also, this unrelated, but the number of dislikes on this video is really disappointing, I thought it was really fascinating and it's too bad people rushed to judgment without actually listening to what you had to say.

I agree that institutional racism is a thing. But the solution is not institutional/systematic, because the root cause any kind of racism is humans being jerks. The solution is, therefore, humans learning not to be jerks. Forcing diversity by introducing institutional measures like providing privileges to minorities is not only unfair to both the majority(who may have worked very hard only to have their opportunity taken away because of such measures) and the minority(who may see such privileges as society looking down on them), it is also failing to address the root cause of the problem.

The problem is not lack of diversity, the problem is humans being jerks. The solution is for humans to stop being jerks. Yes we are biased, but institutional measures will only give us excuses to retain our bias(because our bias is now "compensated" by these measures). We need to get rid of our biases, admit of our own weaknesses, and start seeing fellow humans as just that, fellow humans, in every aspect of life inside and outside the system.

That means when students have questions, you answer; when applicants face financial troubles, you provide; when candidates are qualified, you offer them the position they are applying for. When people ask for help, you help them. It really is that simple, but at the same time difficult, because admitting our biases and removing them is hard. But with bandaid fixes like institutional measures, racism will always remain in some form.

TLDR what part of "love thy neighbour" do you not understand?
